oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Corner of Second Avenue and Broadway
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: View of the Northeast corner of Second Avenue and Broadway showing the businesses on Second Avenue. The Silver Dollar Saloon building. and the Phillips & Quarles Hardware Store in the Watkins Block building are in the foreground. Signs for other businesses on the street include Berry Wholesale Drug Co., American Paper & Twine Co., Max Schatten & Son Wholesale Shoes, Mid-South Shoe Co., McClendon Saddlery Co., and Davis & Cooke. Phillips & Quarles Hardware has an advertisement for Benjamin Moore House paint showing a painter and pick-up truck painted on the brick building side. The street has cars parked down it, including trucks for Mason-Dixon, Truck McLean Company, and Mid-South Transports.

The Silver Dollar Saloon, located at 100 Market Street (Second Avenue), is a three-story Romanesque brick building designed by architect Julius G. Zwicker and completed in 1893. In 1889, V. E. Schwab purchased the property at Broad and Market Street. The building has terra cotta details, including a wreath and shells on the façade. A turret is above the main entrance to the building. Other architectural details include a large cornice with a terracotta frieze, stringcourse molding, and large encased arched windows on the second floor. The building's name came from the floors made of silver dollars. V. E. Schwab was associated with George A. Dickel & Co., as his brother-in-law was George A. Dickel, and the saloon served their whiskey. The saloon attracted riverboat crews who worked nearby, with it offering drinks, lunch, and lodging. During prohibition, the saloon transformed into a soft drink emporium and restaurant. The Watkins Block, located at 108-114 Second Avenue, was built in 1875 by brickmaker Samuel Watkins, a prominent builder in Nashville. The building is a three-story, brick Italianate style building. Paired brackets support the large overhanging cornice. Brick dentil ornamentation runs above the third-story windows. Shouldered metal moldings with keystones accentuate the round windows on the upper floors. The center structure of the block has a dated parapet. Four years after the construction of the building, Samuel Watkins started on plans for the Watkins Institute. Historically, the building had an assortment of different occupiers, such as Herman Bros., Lindauer & Co., the largest wholesale house in 1889, and the laboratories, offices, and warehouses Spurlock Neal Co. Wholesale druggists since the 1890’s.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Boucher, Jack E.; Historic American Buildings Survey
